9. Bioferineries¶

BioSTEAM comes with key biorefinery designs, including a design for 2nd generation ethanol production from corntover and a design for the co-production of ethanol and biodiesel from lipidcane [1, 2]. To load the cornstover biorefinery, simply load the system:

In [1]:

import biosteam as bst
from biosteam.biorefineries.cornstover import system

Now your flowsheet should change to the cornstover biorefinery:

In [2]:

bst.find

Out[2]:

<MainFlowsheet: cornstover>

All systems, unit operations, and streams are registered in your flowsheet:

In [3]:

bst.find.system

Out[3]:

Register:
 <System: pretreatment_sys>
 <System: fermentation_sys>
 <System: ethanol_recycle_sys>
 <System: purification>
 <System: aerobic_digestion_sys>
 <System: cornstover_sys>

By convention, the complete biorefinery system begins with the same name as the flowsheet:

In [4]:

cornstover_sys = bst.find.system.cornstover_sys
cornstover_sys.diagram()

Similarly, you can also load the lipidcane biorefinery:

In [5]:

from biosteam.biorefineries.lipidcane import system
cornstover_sys = bst.find.system.lipidcane_sys
cornstover_sys.diagram()

Note that your flowsheet is now “lipidcane”:

In [6]:

bst.find

Out[6]:

<MainFlowsheet: lipidcane>

You can switch flowsheets anytime with the set_flowsheet method:

In [7]:

bst.find.flowsheet

Out[7]:

Register:
 <Flowsheet: default>
 <Flowsheet: cornstover>
 <Flowsheet: lipidcane>

In [8]:

bst.find.set_flowsheet(bst.find.flowsheet.default)

In [9]:

bst.find

Out[9]:

<MainFlowsheet: default>

You can also import only the Species object used to model the thermodynamic properties, without having to load the whole biorefinery system:

In [10]:

from biosteam.biorefineries.lipidcane import species
# Note: The species module contains all species objects
species.lipidcane_species

Out[10]:

<Species: Glucose, H3PO4, Flocculant, Ethanol, Lignin, Solids, Sucrose, CaO, Ash, Cellulose, Hemicellulose, Lipid, Water, Methanol, Glycerol, Biodiesel, NaOH, HCl, NaOCH3, CO2, Octane, DryYeast>

References

  1. Huang, H., Long, S., & Singh, V. (2016) “Techno-economic analysis of biodiesel and ethanol co-production from lipid-producing sugarcane” Biofuels, Bioproducts and Biorefining, 10(3), 299–315. https://doi.org/10.1002/bbb.1640

  2. Humbird, D., Davis, R., Tao, L., Kinchin, C., Hsu, D., Aden, A., Dudgeon, D. (2011). Process Design and Economics for Biochemical Conversion of Lignocellulosic Biomass to Ethanol: Dilute-Acid Pretreatment and Enzymatic Hydrolysis of Corn Stover (No. NREL/TP-5100-47764, 1013269). https://doi.org/10.2172/1013269
